metadata.key: search:general:6:Claudiu Keșerü influence on football development in Romania

data.title: Claudiu Keșerü - Wikipedia
data.snippet:
Claudiu Andrei Keșerü (Romanian pronunciation: (/wiki/Help:IPA/Romanian "Help:IPA/Romanian"); born 2 December 1986) is a Romanian former professional footballer who played as a striker#Striker "Forward (association football)").

After starting out at his hometown side Bihor Oradea "FC Bihor Oradea (1958)"), Keșerü soon moved to Nantes in 2003. Over the course of nearly eleven years in France, he represented five clubs and amassed Ligue 1 and Ligue 2 totals of 240 appearances and 67 goals. In 2014, he returned to his native country by signing a contract with defending champions Steaua București. [...] Keșerü also had a brief spell with Al-Gharafa in Qatar, before moving to Ludogorets Razgrad in the summer of 2015. He netted more than 110 times in the Bulgarian First League "First Professional Football League (Bulgaria)") and became the foreign player with the most goals in the competition. Keșerü is also the only foreigner to become season top scorer in Bulgaria on more than one occasion. In 2021, he returned to Steaua București—now renamed FCSB.

Keșerü made his first senior international appearance for Romania in October 2013, in a 4–0 defeat of Andorra. He earned over 40 caps "Cap (sport)") for the nation and was part of the squad that participated in UEFA Euro 2016.

## Club career

[edit]

### Bihor Oradea

[edit] [...] ### Retirement and executive career

[edit]

He retired at the end of the contract with Cherno More in December 2024. In January 2025 he became the new sporting director of Romanian Liga II club Bihor Oradea "FC Bihor Oradea (2022)").

## International career

[edit]

On 11 October 2013, Keșerü made his full debut for Romania in a 4–0 win against Andorra, scoring the first goal of the match.

He was selected in Romania's squad for UEFA Euro 2016, playing the full 90 minutes in the second group match against Switzerland. This was Keșerü's only appearance of the tournament, as his country finished bottom of the group.

In 2019, Keșerü scored five goals in three games for Romania in matches against Sweden, the Faroe Islands and Norway counting for the UEFA Euro 2020 qualification.

data.title: Radical Football Conference 2024
data.snippet:
He started football at his hometown club, F.C. Bihor Oradea, before moving to Nantes in 2003. Over the next eleven years in France, he amassed 240 appearances and 67 goals for five clubs in both Ligue 1 and Ligue 2. In 2014, Keșerü returned to Romania, signing with defending champion Steaua Bucharest. His career included a brief spell at Al-Gharafa in Qatar before joining Ludogorets Razgrad in 2015. Here he scored more than 110 goals in the first league and won the title of the competition’s top scorer on several occasions, consolidating his status as the most prolific foreign player in the history of Bulgarian football. In 2021, he returned to Steaua Bucharest, which has since been renamed FCSB, marking a nostalgic homecoming for the experienced striker. After leaving FCSB, Keșerü signed [...] the experienced striker. After leaving FCSB, Keșerü signed a contract with UTA Arad and is currently developing professionally to pursue an administrative career in football. [...] Claudiu Keseru

#### Claudiu Keseru

Former player of the Romanian national football team. The most prolific foreign player in the history of Bulgarian football.

##### Experience

data.title: FC Bihor Oradea (1958) - Wikipedia
data.snippet:
Youth academy of FC Bihor gave important names for the Romanian and international football such as: Sebastian Achim, Cosmin Bărcăuan, Zeno Bundea, Cristian Cigan, Viorel Domocoș, Ioan Filip, Ramses Gado, Ovidiu Hoban, Claudiu Keșerü, Attila Kun "Attila Kun (footballer, born 1949)"), Ovidiu Lazăr, Raymond Lukacs, Marius Popa, Daniel Usvat or Ion Zare. After the declaration of bankruptcy, CSM Oradea announced the establishment of the football department and took the youth academy of FC Bihor.

## Grounds

[edit&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Grounds")]

The club played its home matches on Stadionul Iuliu Bodola from Oradea. The second team and youth teams played their matches on Stadionul Motorul "Stadionul Motorul (Oradea)"), also located in Oradea.

data.title: Report: Rapids interested in veteran Romanian striker Claudiu Keseru
data.snippet:
Keseru currently plays his club football with Bulgarian side Ludogorets, where he was the league's top scorer with 22 goals during the 2016-17 campaign. Internationally, the 31-year-old has scored six goals in 23 appearances for Romania, including three during 13 appearances in qualifiers for either the World Cup or European Championships.

Colorado are expected to take a more attack-minded approach under new coach Anthony Hudson, and would stand to need more striking depth if they go ahead with an expected switch to a 3-5-2 formation this year. [...] Keseru spent a sizable chunk of his early pro career in the first and second divisions in France before stints at Steaua Bucharest in his native Romania and Al-Gharafa in Qatar. He's seen action in UEFA Champions League and Europa League matches both at Steaua and with Ludogorets since his move to Bulgaria before the 2015-16 season.

Ian Nicholas Quillen -

 @IaqDiesel

 Colorado Rapids

# Report: Rapids interested in veteran Romanian striker Claudiu Keseru

Ian Nicholas Quillen

 Share on Facebook
 Share on X

TRANSFER TRACKER STATUS:Report

The Colorado Rapids appear to be in the market for another striker, and one target could be Romanian international Claudiu Keseru, according to Metro US's Kristian Dyer.

> Hearing from source that Colorado Rapids have some interest in Ludogorets striker Claudiu Keseru.
>
> — Kristian Dyer (@KristianRDyer) January 15, 2018

data.title: Liga I - Grokipedia
data.snippet: Dudu Georgescu holds the record for the most goals scored in Liga I history, with 252 goals during his career primarily with Dinamo București between 1969 and 1984. His prolific scoring included four seasons as the league's top scorer, peaking with 36 goals in the 1976–77 campaign, a single-season record that remains unmatched. Other notable all-time scorers include Ionel Dănciulescu with 214 goals across multiple clubs from 1995 to 2017, and Claudiu Keșerü with 127 goals from 2005 to 2022. In terms of appearances, Valentin Stănescu leads with 490 matches for FC Argeș Pitești between 1969 and 1987, followed by Constantin Stancu with 447 games for the same club from 1976 to 1990. These longevity records highlight the endurance required in Romania's top flight, where players like Mário [...] The Divizia A, Romania's premier professional football league, was established in the 1921–22 season as the country's first nationwide competition, initially featuring eight teams drawn from regional champions to foster a unified national structure beyond the previous regional tournaments. This marked a significant step in professionalizing the sport, with Chinezul Timișoara emerging as the inaugural champions after defeating Jahn Sibiu 2–1 in the final. The league gradually expanded to accommodate growing participation, reaching 16 teams by the 1932–33 season, which allowed for broader representation across Romania's regions and intensified competition among emerging powerhouses like Ripensia Timișoara and Venus București. The league's development was profoundly disrupted by World War [...] league's development was profoundly disrupted by World War II, with operations suspended from 1940 to 1944 due to the conflict's impact on infrastructure, player availability, and national stability; an unofficial championship was held in 1942–43, won by FC Craiova, but it lacked official recognition. Post-war reconstruction under the communist regime beginning in 1947 led to the nationalization of clubs, stripping private ownership and aligning them with state institutions—for instance, the army-backed Clubul Central al Armatei (CCA) was rebranded as Steaua București in 1961, symbolizing the regime's integration of sport into military and ideological frameworks.
